title: Ang momentum cons - ball-platform and dart-circle

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A platform with an irregular shape is mounted on a vertical axle through its center, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and can rotate freely with negligible friction about the axle. A group of students wants to determine the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub P" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math> of the platform about the axle. They have a collection of small metal balls that are the same size but have different, known masses. They also have a launcher that can launch the metal balls at a fixed, known velocity <math alttext="v sub L" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>L</mtext></msub></math>.

The students decide to launch the metal balls horizontally, each toward the same location on the platform, where they get stuck after colliding (but can be removed later), as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The balls stick in the platform at a distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> from the platform’s center.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine the value of <math alttext="I sub P" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math> by making a linear graph. In your description, include the measurements to be made along with the corresponding equipment needed for each measurement. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A platform with an irregular shape is mounted on a vertical axle through its center, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and can rotate freely with negligible friction about the axle. A group of students wants to determine the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub P" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math> of the platform about the axle. They have a collection of small metal balls that are the same size but have different, known masses. They also have a launcher that can launch the metal balls at a fixed, known velocity <math alttext="v sub L" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>L</mtext></msub></math>.

The students decide to launch the metal balls horizontally, each toward the same location on the platform, where they get stuck after colliding (but can be removed later), as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The balls stick in the platform at a distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> from the platform’s center.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine the value of <math alttext="I sub P" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math> by making a linear graph. In your description, include the measurements to be made along with the corresponding equipment needed for each measurement. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph could be analyzed to determine <math alttext="I sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math>.

Next, the students are given circular platform of known rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub C equals 0.0120 kilogram meters squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.0120</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>·</mo><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Like the earlier platform, the circular platform is mounted to a vertical axle at its center and can rotate freely with negligible friction about the axle, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. The students also have a dart and wish to determine its mass <math alttext="m sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math> by doing a collision experiment.

As shown in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, the students can launch the dart horizontally toward the circle with a speed of <math alttext="v sub L equals 8.00 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>L</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>8.00</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>, which is the same for every launch. With the circular platform initially at rest, the dart gets launched parallel to, and a distance <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math> from, a line passing through the circle’s center, as indicated. The dart then sticks in the platform wherever it hits at the platform’s edge. No matter where the dart sticks, the dart’s center of mass ends up at the same distance <math alttext="r sub D equals 0.200 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.200</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> from the center of the circle, as indicated.

The students perform multiple experimental trials, each time launching the dart at a different distance <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math> and then determining the dart-platform’s rotational speed <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math> after the collision. The results of their experiment are shown in the table.

(c)

i. Indicate what quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="m sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math>.

Horizontal axis: __________          Vertical axis: __________

Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units.

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii), calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="m sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>D</mtext></msub></math>.
